2. Hello, World!

2.1 Programs

Program is a command which tells the computer what to do. Programming is an activity of writing and testing such programs.

Computers are dumb, in the sense that they require instructions to complete a certain task that a human can do with common sense.
The language in which instructions are given is programming language. C++ would be our programming language.

2.2 The classic first program

Classic Hello World Program 

                // This program outpts "Hello World" to the monitor
                #include <iostream>
                int main() {
                    cout <<"Hello, World!\n";
                    return 0;
                }

Let's look at the meaning of each line:

  1. // is a comment. It is ignored by the compiler. Written to make code more readable.
  2. #include is a directive; it instructs the compiler to include facilities from iostream.
  3. main is the function where the computer starts executing the code.
  4. cout refers to the standard output stream, it is an abbreviaton of "character output". Character put in cout using << will appear on screen (by default -- that can be changed by how you invoke the program).

Every C++ program should have a main function to tell from where to start executing the program. A function has four parts:

  1. return type specifies type of result that particular function would return to the callee. int here.
  2. name, here main
  3. Parameter list list of arguments the function takes.empty in the above example
  4. function body enclosed in curly braces,which lists the actions
2.3 Compilation

C++ is a compiled language which means that the code has to be translated to machine instructions before the program is run, by a compiler. (A language like Python translates to machine language as the program is run, without a separate compile step.)

Source code is the code you write, for C++ the suffix is .cpp. The machine code or object code, is .o (Unix) or .obj(Windows)

Compiler checks for grammatically errors and/or syntax.

2.4 Linking

Several parts of code must be compiled and the resulting object files must be linked together to form an executable. The linker does this.

Object code and executables are not portable among systems i.e. object code for Windows will not run on Unix machines.

Compile time errors: errors found by the compiler.
Link time errors: errors found by the linker.
Run time/logical errors: found when program is run.

2.5 Programming environments

To program we either use the command line or an IDE. To write and run a program, we require a compiler, a linker and an editor.

  • When using the command line, you need to compile and link code by typing commands.
  • In an IDE (Interactive Development Environment) you simply click a button, which performs the compile, link, and run commands for you. IDEs also have features like color coding to help distinguish between comments, keywords and other parts of program.

Debugging is used to find errors in program and remove them.
